docs.snippet: Donald Brashear, the former N.H.L. enforcer, talked about his hockey life shortly before sparking a bench-clearing brawl in Trois-Rivières last week....
docs.lead_paragraph: That clip above is of Donald Brashear going nuts in Trois-Rivières, Quebec, last Friday night. He attacked two opponents -- three, if you count the one gloved punch he threw at a forward who just happened to be standing there -- in the semipro Ligue Nord-Américaine de Hockey. (Full Times article on the "Slap Shot"-like league at this link.) It was only the second fight Brashear has had this season in the mayhem-filled L.N.A.H. -- he had 278 in 16 seasons in the N.H.L. -- but it was a doozy. The account of the game from Steve Turcotte of Le Nouvelliste describes the fight and the postgame reaction of Brashear and both coaches; if you can't read it in French, run it through Google's translator tool.

headline.main: Brashear on Hockey, Fighting and His Lost Rangers Season

docs.abstract: Donald Brashear, the former N.H.L. enforcer, talked about his hockey life shortly before sparking a bench-clearing brawl in Trois-Rivières last week.

docs.snippet: ABC took a break on Monday night from providing a 24-hour platform for Charlie Sheen so it could briefly address the more pressing business of unveiling the next cast of contenders for ''Dancing With the Stars.'' The roster of semi- and never-were...
docs.lead_paragraph: ABC took a break on Monday night from providing a 24-hour platform for Charlie Sheen so it could briefly address the more pressing business of unveiling the next cast of contenders for ''Dancing With the Stars.'' The roster of semi- and never-were-celebs for the 12th season of that popular reality competition may not include anyone as instantly fascinating as, say, Bristol Palin, who danced her way to a third-place finish on the show last fall, and producers were apparently unsuccessful in casting their spell over Christine O'Donnell, the Republican senatorial candidate from Delaware, to take part in the new cycle. But when the new season of ''Dancing'' makes its debut on March 21, the contestants will include Kirstie Alley, the ''Cheers'' and ''Look Who's Talking'' star; Ralph Macchio, the original ''Karate Kid''; the talk-show host Wendy Williams; the hall of fame boxer Sugar Ray Leonard; and the Pittsburgh Steelers wide receiver Hines Ward. The people we had to Google include Chris Jericho, a professional wrestler; Chelsea Kane, a Disney Channel actor; Kendra Wilkinson, a Playboy model and reality television star; and ''Psycho'' Mike Catherwood, a co-host of the radio program ''Loveline.'' Also competing this season is the rapper Romeo, who was scheduled to be part of the show in 2006, but dropped out because of an injury and was replaced by his father, the rapper Master P.

headline.main: 'Dancing With the Stars' Reveals Competitors

docs.abstract: ABC announces contenders for next season of Dancing With the Stars, including Kirstie Alley, Ralph Macchio, Wendy Williams, Sugar Ray Leonard, Kendra Wilkinson, and Hines Ward (S)

docs.snippet: Ever check into a hotel only to be disappointed that your pricey deluxe suite sits on the second floor and has a view of a parking garage? A new Web site and free iPhone app  called Room 77 seeks to help you avoid this fate.      It has turned fin...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ever check into a hotel only to be disappointed that your pricey deluxe suite sits on the second floor and has a view of a parking garage? A new Web site and free iPhone app called Room 77 seeks to help you avoid this fate. It has turned finding the best room in the house into a science by opening up a database of 425,000 rooms in 16 cities to users who want to search within hotels for rooms according to preferences like the floor number, proximity to elevators and whether there's a connecting room. Users can click on the results to get a Google Earth-enabled preview of what the view looks like (based on the longitude, latitude and altitude of the room) and a floor plan.

headline.main: Room With a View? An App to Tell You

docs.abstract: In Transit blog; new iPhone app Room 77 allows users to search hotels for particular preferences in rooms, like type of view or proximity to an elevator; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As this book review points out, in the age of Google and cellphones, fewer of us are memorizing "the basic data of daily life." And though teachers used to ask students to memorize poetry and speeches, that, too, is happening less. What do you have memorized? What, whether a poem, your friend's phone number, the lyrics to a song or a recipe, do you wish you had memorized? Why?

docs.snippet: Hewlett-Packard, Google, Apple and Medtronic all have thousands of employees who work in shiny corporate offices. But it wasn't always that way. In fact, all four companies got their start in humble garages. Steve Jobs, for one, worked in his pare...
docs.lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard, Google, Apple and Medtronic all have thousands of employees who work in shiny corporate offices. But it wasn't always that way. In fact, all four companies got their start in humble garages. Steve Jobs, for one, worked in his parents' garage to build the very first Apple computer. Was it something about the garage environment itself that caused these four companies to thrive? Could be. After all, when you work in a garage, operating costs are low, tinkering is encouraged, and it's O.K. to get your hands dirty -- three important factors that lead to entrepreneurial success, and to outgrowing the garage.

headline.main: The Smell of Success (and Motor Oil)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The most highly acclaimed show on television and it can't get back on the air? Unacceptable.'' Roberta Lipp, who with her sister Deborah operates a ''Mad Men'' fan site. The show's next season may not start until late 2011 or early 2012 because of money disputes involving the creator, the studio and the network. ''It's pretty much a goat rodeo until someone sorts it out.'' Drew Sievers, chief executive of mFoundry, which makes mobile payment software for merchants and banks. Banks are competing with carriers and companies like Apple and Google for a piece of the mobile payment market.

docs.snippet: "Sadako and the Thousand Paper Cranes" and the not-Disney ending in children's literature....
docs.lead_paragraph: The other day my daughter came home from school excited about having read the book "Sadako and the Thousand Paper Cranes." She grabbed the book out of her backpack, opened it to the end, and told me to read the last line. I did, and then had to read the whole thing (it doesn't take long, though you have to get an actual bound copy; the Google book is partial). The true story of Sadako Sasaki is well known in Japan, and the book by Eleanor Coerr is a staple of elementary-school curricula and class projects in the United States, so chances are you know the basic outline: A Japanese girl gets leukemia as a result of radiation from the bombing of Hiroshima. A friend tells her that if she folds 1,000 paper cranes, her wish to be made well will come true. I couldn't find much about Eleanor Coerr online beyond that she was a Canadian who had spent time in Japan, and died last year at age 88. She wrote in spare, descriptive prose, and I understand why my daughter was stunned by the last line. Here it is, in context:

headline.main: Fairy Tale Endings?

docs.abstract: "Sadako and the Thousand Paper Cranes" and the not-Disney ending in children's literature.
